151.0: A piece of fatty kosher meat that was roasted with lean non-kosher meat is prohibited.

150.56: And this statement is when it's raw, but roasted, it needs [removal of] a peel.
150.42: Hot into cold - peel; cold into cold - rinse.
150.48: "Salted is like hot, pickled is like cooked."
150.53: Who is wise enough to permit a matter like this if not Rav Hinena bar Rava of Pashrona who is a great person!
150.24: but if it is of Israelites; if it is raw, they must wash it off; if it is roasted, one must peel off the outer [surface].
150.25: This works for Rav, who says the top one determines, for that reason [removing] a peel-worth is sufficient, because the top one [the oil] is cold.
150.26: But for Shmuel who says that the bottom one determines, since it's hot it will surely absorb! Why is [removing] a peel-worth sufficient?
150.21: Rav Yirmiah says in the name of Shmuel,
150.23: The Mishnah teaches: If one anointed [basted] it with oil that was terumah, and the company appointed to eat it [consists of] Kohanim, they may eat it;
150.46: This is only taught when it's not salty, but if it's salted it's prohibited.
150.28: Anointing is different, since he just did a small amount [and it's not sufficiently much to make it forbidden].
150.29: A Braita teaches similarly to Shmuel:
150.40: Since it's hot, it must absorb a bit before it cools off!  Rather, require [removing] a peel.
150.1: Cold into cold, everyone says it's permitted.
150.2: Hot into cold, and cold into hot -
150.4: the top one determines and Shmuel says
150.7: If its juices dripped onto the ceramic, and [dripped] back onto [the lamb, that part of the meat] must be taken off.
150.9: This works for Rav, who says the top one determines, for that reason you take the piece off, because the juice heated the ceramic and the ceramic then heated the juice.
150.8: You assume it refers to cold ceramic
150.51: There was a bird that fell into a jar of Kamka [milk based porridge].  Rav Hinena bar Rava of Pashrona permitted it.
150.38: Hot into cold, and cold into cold - rinse.
150.58: And it it's spiced, it's prohibited.
150.11: But for Shmuel who says that the bottom one determines, since the ceramic is cold it will cool down the juice.  Why take a piece off?
150.10: When the juice goes back on the lamb, the lamb is cooked from the heat of the ceramic, and the Torah states "fire roasted" - and not roasted by something else
150.13: "[the Mishnah refers] to hot flour", here to
150.12: It's like Rav Yirmiah says in the name of Shmuel,
150.17: You assume it refers to cold flour
150.16: If the dripping fell on [hot] fine flour, one should take [that part of the flour] in a handful [and burn it].
150.19: But for Shmuel who says that the bottom one determines, since the flour is cold it will cool down [the juice].  Why take a handful out?
150.18: This works for Rav, who says the top one determines, for that reason you take a handful out, because [the juice] heated the flour around it and then it heated itself, and the juice is cooked from the heat of the flour, and the Torah states "fire roasted" - and not roasted by something else.
150.31: Hot into cold and cold into cold - rinse.
150.30: Hot into hot is prohibited, and also cold that is placed into hot is prohibited.
150.37: Hot meat that falls into hot milk, and also cold that falls into hot, are prohibited.
150.35: Hot into cold - peel; cold into cold - rinse.
150.33: Since it's hot, it must absorb a bit before it cools off!  Rather, require [removing] a peel.
150.55: When Shmuel said "Salted is like hot...", it's only when it can't be eaten because of it's saltiness. This can be eaten even with its saltiness.
150.57: And it's only said when there are no cracks, but if there are cracks, it is prohibited.
150.50: That which Shmuel says, "Salted is like hot...", is only said when it can't be eaten because of it's saltiness.  But if it can be eaten [even] because of its saltiness, it doesn't apply.

214.42: And Rabbi Yehoshua the son of Levi said
214.43: Women are obligated in the mitzvah of (drinking) four cups
214.24: Now that it was stated as such and stated as such, both these (first cups) and these (last cups) require reclining
214.25: Lying on one's back is not called "reclining." Reclining to the right is not called "reclining." More so, maybe the windpipe will precede the esophagus and one will come to danger.
214.26: A woman next to her husband does not need to recline, but if she is an important woman, she needs to recline.
214.27: A son in presence of his father needs to recline.
214.20: that the first two cups require reclining because now our freedom begins
214.21: and the last two cups don't require reclining because what happened has happened.
214.23: Indeed it is the opposite! The last two cups require reclining because that is when freedom is a reality. The first two cups do not require reclining because we are in the midst of reciting "We were slaves to Pharaoh in Egypt."
214.29: What is the law of a student next to his Rabbi?
214.40: If he reclined, yes (he fulfilled his obligation). If he did not recline, he does not.
214.41: Learn from here that reclining is required.
214.39: A waiter who ate an olive's weight of matza while reclining has fulfilled his obligation.
214.38: Come and learn: For Rabbi Yehoshua son of Levi said
214.13: Matsa requires reclining; marror does not require reclining.
214.15: that it needs reclining. And it was also stated in the name of Rabbi Nachman
214.14: With regards to wine, it was stated in the name of Rabbi Nachman
214.17: But there is no dispute (between the two statements). One statement refers to the first two cups and one statement refers to the last two cups
214.16: that it does not need reclining
214.18: Some people explain it this way and some explain it another way
214.31: When we were students in the School of Master (Rabbah), we would lean on each other's knees. But when we came to the School of Rav Yosef, he said to us:
214.37: What is the law regarding a waiter?
214.35: When was that Beraita taught? With regards to the apprentice of carpenters.
214.34: A person must recline in front of everyone and even a student next to his Rabbi.
214.32: "You don't need to (recline). For the fear of your Rabbi is as your fear of Heaven."

215.24: Everyone is obligated in drinking four glasses of wine, be it men, women and children.
215.26: What purpose is their in that children should drink the four cups of wine?
215.27: Rather, we distribute to them( the children)
215.1: Rav Yehuda said in the name of Shmuel:
215.0: Since even they were part of that miracle.
215.3: If you drank the four cups without diluting them with water, you have fulfilled your obligation. If you drank the four cups all together(Rashi's understanding) OR If you drank the four cups in a straight fashion without following the order prescribed by our Mishnah(Rashbam's understanding). If you poured bits of your glass of wine to members of the family or others sitting around the table, you have still fulfilled your obligation even though you haven't drunken the entire glass of wine.
215.2: The four cups of wine during Seder night must have enough to fill a generous cup.
215.4: If you drank the four glasses of wine without diluting them, you have fulfilled your obligation.
215.7: If you drink the four glasses of wine one after the other without pausing in between to mention the required parts of the Haggadah(Rashbam's understanding) then Rav says
215.6: You have fulfilled your obligation of drinking four glasses of wine on Pesach, however, you have not fulfilled your obligation of making yourself free as a slave.
215.9: If a person poured from his cup to his children and did not drink a full cup, he has still fulfilled his obligation.
215.8: You have fulfilled your obligation of drinking wine, but you have not fulfilled your obligation to drink the four glasses of wine on Pesach night,
215.11: He only fulfils his obligation if he drank the majority of the glass of wine.
215.10: Rav Nachman, the son of Itzchak says
215.12: The Gemara now asks on the previous statement that requires one to drink the majority of the glass on Pesach to fulfill the mitzvah of four cups:

199.11: But the one who taught "They agree that one may begin," when is that?

199.15: Those people that have kiddush made for them in the synagogue:
199.14: here [where they agree] is before the 9th hour, there [where they argue whether one may begin] is after the 9th hour.
199.17: "They have not completed their duty for wine, but for kiddush, they have completed their duty."

199.2: Is it not [referring to] removal of the table [like that of Rabbi Yehuda]?

199.4: Rabbah bar Rav Huna visited the exilarch.

198.21: "If so, we should not stop, lest the students see and establish it that way forever."
198.23: they did not budge until they established the law like Rabbi Yossi.

198.29: "Just like one should stop [the meal] for kiddush,
198.1: Mareimar, and some say it was Rav Yeimar, said,
198.3: If so, then this is a difficulty!

198.5: it's clear [the answer is] according to Rav Huna.
198.7: But Rabbi Yirmiya said in the name of Rabbi Yochanan, and some say it was Rabbi Abahu in the name of Rabbi Yossi the son of Rabbi Chanina,
198.6: Is this really well for Rav Huna?
198.9: "The law is like Rabbi Yehuda..." implies that Rabbi Yossi is arguing on both [the eve of Pesach and the Sabbath]!
198.8: "The law is like Rabbi Yehuda on the eve of Pesach, and like Rabbi Yossi on the eve of the Sabbath."
198.11: As it is taught [in a baraita],
198.10: No, "the law is..." implies they argue about stopping [the meal].
198.12: "We stop [eating] for the Sabbaths, these are the words of Rabbi Yehuda.
198.15: An occurrence happened that Rabbi Shimon ben Gamliel and Rabbi Yehuda and Rabbi Yossi were eating in Acre, and the day became holy [the Sabbath having started].
198.17: "Do you want to stop and be concerned for the opinion of Rabbi Yehuda our colleague?"
198.16: Rabbi Shimon ben Gamliel said to Rabbi Yossi,
198.19: "Each and every day you have favored my opinions over Rabbi Yehuda's, and now you are favoring Rabbi Yehuda's over mine? 'Even to take the queen while I'm in the house?' [Esther 7:8]".

210.11: Is not the night the principal time of the Sabbath, when the Kiddush must be said? Then, again, how can the passage refer to the night, when it distinctly states the day? The following is meant: "Remember the day" implies that it should be remembered over wine, when the Sabbath sets in. This therefore refers to the night, and that the day also is meant is clearly proven by the words, "the Sabbath day."
210.10: "How do we know that the night is also meant," is the question?
210.9: This, however, refers to the Sabbath day; how do we know that the night is also meant? To that end it is written, 'to keep it holy,' which refers also to the night."
210.8: The rabbis taught: "It is written [Exod.20:8]: 'Remember the Sabbath day to keep it holy.' The remembrance should be effected over wine.

197.10: One may continue to eat until it gets dark. When do these words apply? To the eves of the Sabbaths and Festivals, but to the eve of Pesach, because there is the obligation of Matza, he would agree [that one may not eat on the eve of Pesach]."
197.13: But on the eve of Pesach, even close to Mincha would be forbidden."
197.12: "Even if you'll say [this Mishna is also needed within] Rabbi Yehuda, there [where he forbade eating] for eves of Sabbaths and Festivals, that was a prohibition from Mincha and on, but close to Mincha was permitted.
197.15: But it is taught [in a Baraita],
197.14: And would close to Mincha on the eve of the Sabbath be permitted [for eating]?
197.17: One may continue to eat unto it gets dark."
197.16: "One may not eat on the eve of Sabbath and Festivals from 9 hours and on, in order that one may enter the Sabbath with an appetite, these are the words of Rabbi Yehuda. Rabbi Yossi says,
197.19: "Who says that this [text] is a correct one?
197.18: [Thus, close to Mincha is also forbidden according to Rabbi Yehuda!] Mar Zutra said,
197.1: Even an poor Jew cannot eat until he leans [at the Seder].
197.0: Mishna: The eve of Pesach, close to [the time of] Mincha, one may not eat until it gets dark.
197.3: Gemara: Why deal [specifically] with "eves of Pesachs"?
197.2: And they should not [give] less to him than the 4 cups of wine, even from the soup kitchen.
197.5: "One may not eat on the eves of Sabbaths and Festivals from Mincha and on, so that one can enter the Sabbath with an appetite, these are the words of Rabbi Yehuda.
197.4: Even the eves of Sabbaths and Festivals also [one may not eat from close to Mincha until nightfall], as it is taught [in a Baraita],
197.7: One may continue to eat until it gets dark."
197.9: "This [Mishna] is only needed for Rabbi Yossi, who said,
197.8: [So why deal with eves of Pesachs in our Mishna?] Rav Huna said,

227.24: as is taught [in a Baraitha]: Rabbi Yohanan ben Nuri says:
227.25: Rice is a form of grain, and for its leavening one is liable for karet (=expungement), and one may fulfill his obligation [to eat matza] with it on Passover.
227.27: Even fish with egg on it
227.20: Rava would look for beets and rice since this teaching came from the mouth of Rav Huna.
227.22: Learn that which Rav Huna said:
227.23: Nobody follows Rabbi Yohanan ben Nuri,
227.29: You need two kinds of meat, one in commemoration of Korban Pesach and one in commemoration of Korban Chagigah.
227.1: This indicates that commandments require intent.
227.3: For if you think that commandments don't need intent then why do I need two dippings?
227.2: For since one is eating the first portion of lettuce not at the time of maror, but rather when he just recites "boreh peri ha'adama", therefore he must dip again for the sake of maror.
227.5: From what proof do you say this?
227.6: Maybe commandments do not require intent and that which you asked "why do I need two dippings?" I will answer you so that there will be something different (recognizable) for the children.
227.9: I would have said that two dippings are required when there are other vegetables, however when there is only one lettuce, it isn't required. It comes to teach us...
227.8: "If so, then the mishna should have mentioned other vegetables!" I would have answered you
227.11: And furthermore, it was taught in a Beraita
227.10: that even when there is only one lettuce we require two dippings so that there will be a something different (recognizable) for the children.
227.13: It's a dispute among Tanaim. For it as taught in a Beraita, Rabbi Yose says
227.12: If he ate them while they were "demai," he fulfilled the mitzvah. If he ate them without intent, he fulfilled the mitzvah. If he ate them in halves, he fulfilled the mitzvah on condition that he doesn't wait too much between one eating and the other more than it takes to eat a peras.
227.14: Even though he dipped and ate lettuce, it is a mitzvah to bring (another) lettuce, charoset and two cooked dishes.
227.16: Maybe Rabbi Yossi holds that commandments do not require intent, and that which we need two dippings is so that there will be something different (recognizable) for the children! If so, what is the meaning of "mitzvah?"
227.31: Even a bone in its broth.

130.26: It says (Numbers 28:2) "its season" and it says regarding the korban tamid "its season"

130.22: Do we not have more than two hundred Pesachim each year that override Shabbat?

130.12: One time the 14th of Nissan occurred on Shabbat and they did not know if the Korban Pesach overrides Shabbat or not.
130.14: Is there anyone here that knows if the Korban Pesach overrides Shabbat or not?
130.17: They sent for him and called to him....

130.19: Do you know if the Korban Pesach overrides Shabbat or not?
130.37: Rather leave it to the Israel, for if they are not prophets, they are the sons of prohets...

82.50: it confounds the heart, blinds the eyes, and weakens the body

231.17: One needs to raise the matsa and one needs to raise the marror.
231.18: One does not need to raise the meat; and not only that, but [if one does raise it,] it appears like one is eating [sacrifices] outside [of the Temple].
231.0: these three things on Pessah has not fulfilled their obligation
231.3: Pessah, because the omnipresent passed over the houses of our forefathers in Egypt, as it is stated: "and you should state: this is the offering of pessah to Hashem, that he passed over..." Matza because our forefathers were redeemed from Egypt as it is stated: "and they baked the dough which they brought out go egypt ..." Maror because the Egyptians made the lives of our forefathers in Egypt bitter as it is stated: "and their lives were made bitter..."
231.5: Therefore we are obligated to offer effusive, beautiful praise and thanksgiving to the One who performed all these miracles for our ancestors and for us: He brought us from servitude to freedom, from grief to joy, from mourning to festivity, from darkness to great light, and from subjugation to redemption; and let us say before Him "Halleluyah!"
231.4: In each and every generation one is obligated to see themselves as if they went out from Egypt, as it says (Exodus 13:8) And you shall tell you child on that day, saying: Because of this, YHVH did for me when I went out from Egypt.

232.1: and then he uttered [that] song; ‘a psalm of david’ intimates that he [first] uttered [that particular]
232.0: To David, a psalm’ intimates that the Shechinah rested upon him
232.3: neither in indolence nor in gloom nor in frivolity nor in levity, nor in vain pursuits,
232.2: psalm and then the Shechinah rested upon him. This teaches you that the Shechinah rests [upon man]
232.5: rejoicing connected with a religious act, for it is said, ‘but now bring me a minstrel.’ And it came to
232.6: pass, when the minstrel played, that he hand of the lord came upon him.

48.1: R. Jacob said in the name of R. Jochanan: "By every means, one may cure himself except by means of the tree devoted to idolatry." To what case does he refer? If we assume that he refers to a case where there is fear of danger, then why not cure by means of the tree devoted to idolatry? But if he refers to a case in which there is no fear of danger, then one is prohibited to be cured by means of any prohibited articles. Indeed, he does refer to a case where there is fear of danger, nevertheless it is forbidden [to be cured] by means of a tree devoted to ideolatry. As we are taught in a Baraitha, R. Eliezer says: "Since it is said (Deuteronomy 6:5) [Thou shalt love thy God] with all thy soul, wherefore is added, With all thy wealth? And since it is said, With all thy wealtlh, wherefore is also added, With all thy soul? This is to teach us that in case there is a man who loves himself more than his wealth, for him it is said, With all thy soul. And if there is a man who loves his wealth more than himself, for him it is said, With all thy wealth.

230.56: We are no longer obligated dot say Ma Nishtana
230.54: He must thank him and praise him
230.42: "It is an obligation?(that we dip twice) Only for Children!" (So that they will ask questions)
230.48: "At first, our ancestors were idol worshipers."
230.43: But rather, said Rav Safra, "This is how it is taught:
230.52: A Servent whose master made him free, and gave him silver and gold, what does he have to say to him (his master)
230.24: A second cup [of wine] would be mixed for him.  And here the son asks [questions to] his father.
230.25: And if the son has no understanding [in order to ask questions], his father teaches him [to ask]:
230.26: "Why is this night different from all [other] nights? On all [other] nights, we eat chamets (leavened grain products) and matsa, [but] on this night, it is all matsa.
230.27: On all [other] nights, we eat other vegetables, [but] on this night, it is all bitter herbs.
230.44: On all [other] nights, we do not dip even once, [but] on this night, we dip twice."
230.45: He begins [instructing him about the Exodus story] with [the account of Israel’s] shame and concludes with [Israel’s] praise [glory]:
230.28: On all [other] nights, we eat meat roasted, stewed or boiled, [but] on this night, it is all roasted.
230.29: On all [other] nights, we (are not obligated to) dip [vegetables] (even) once, [but] on this night, we dip [vegetables] twice."
230.40: On all [other] nights, we are not obligated to dip even one time, [but] on this night, we [are obligated to] dip twice."
230.41: Rav Safra attacked it (with his logic),
230.51: Rav Nachman said to Doro his servant
230.39: But rather (this is an answer), said Rava, "This is how it is taught:
230.38: "Is it that on every day, it is not enough not to dip one time [and we are actually obligated to dip every night]?"
230.31: He begins [instructing him about the Exodus story] with [the account of Israel’s] shame and concludes with [Israel’s] praise (glory); and expounds from “My father was a wandering Aramean” (Deuteronomy 26:5) until he completes the whole entire passage.
230.30: And according to the son's understanding, his father instructs him.
230.36: "Why is this night different from all [other] nights? On all [other] nights, we dip [vegetables] once, [but] on this night, we dip [vegetables] twice":
230.35: And even if there are two Talmeidi Chachamim who know the laws of Pesach, they ask each other.
230.34: And if there is no wife he asks the questions to himself
230.33: If the son is  smart he asks him (his father questions). If there is no smart son, his wife asks him the questions
230.32: It was taught to us in a Brysa...
230.57: He (Rav Nachman) started to say Avadim Hayinu

43.39: "The Eth [of "Thou shalt fear the LORD, thy God"] includes the scholars."
43.38: But when R. Akiba came, he interpreted:
43.37: "Just as well as I will be rewarded for making those interpretations, so will I be rewarded for refraining in this case."
43.35: "Why, Rabbi, what will become of those Eth's thou didst interpret?"
43.33: When he reached the Eth of (Deuteronomy 6:13, Deuteronomy 10:20) "Thou shalt fear the LORD, thy God", he refrained [did not interpret it].
43.32: that Simon of Amsuni, and others say, Nehemiah of Amsuni,was accustomed to interpret every word Eth.

40.14: ...Every moment that one is allowed to eat hametz, he is allowed to feed his domesticated animal, wild animal, and birds; and he could sell the hametz to a gentile, and he is allowed to derive benefit. When the time elapses, he is forbidden to derive benefit and he could not ignite his oven or stove with the hametz.

41.2: ...And one is allowed to derive benefit:
41.5: ...And it comes to teach us like the opinion of Rava that Rava says
41.4: ...No, it is necessary - that the hametz is cinged before its time
41.6: It was cinged before the time, one could derive benefit even after its time.

2.1: 2  Any place where Chametz is not brought into does not require checking.  And what about what was said about (checking) two rows in a cellar? (This is a case of) a place where Chametz is brought into.  Beit Shamai say the two upermost rows of the wine cellar (require checking).  Beit Hillel say the two outermost rows (require checking).
2.0: 1 At "Or" (lit. Light) on the fourteenth one checks for Chametz (unleavened product) by the light of a candle.
2.7: ... [Gemara:] What is the meaning of אור?
2.6: You might of thought that the one (Rav Huna) who says morning means "morning" itself and the one (Rav Yehudah) who says night means "night" itself.  [We raise a] challenge [on this]
2.8: ... (Beraishit 44:3) "The morning lightened, and the people were sent off". Therefore,

5.1: There were two disciples sitting before Hillel, of whom one was R. Jochanan b. Zakai. According to others, these disciples were sitting before Rabbi, and one of them was R. Jochanan. One said [while studying a Mishnah]: "Why must the grapes be cut according to the rules of levital cleanliness, while olives may be gathered even according to the rules of levitical defilement?" The other pupil said: "Why must the grapes be cut under the rules of levitical cleanliness, while the gathering of olives need not be made under the rules of levitical cleanliness?" "I am sure," remarked their teacher, "that this one [who used becoming words] will become a judge in Israel." It is said that before many days had elapsed he became a judge in Israel.  There were three priests [discussing the portions of their priestly gifts]; one said: "Mine was as large as a bean." To this the other responded: "Mine, was as large as an olive." The third one said: "Mine was as large as the tail of a lizard." In consequence of that unfit expression, the last was examined as to his fitness to serve upon the altar and they found in him a blemish of descent. Have we not been taught [in a Mishnah] ''No family records are searched beyond the altar"? [for he was certainly examined before he began serving upon it; hence how was this examination possible?] Do not say a "blemish of descent," but say [they found in him] "obscenity which made him unworthy of the priesthood." And if you please, you may say this instance differs, because he harmed himself by causing the investigation].
5.3: When R. Cahana became ill, the Rabbis sent R. Joshua, the son of R. Ide, with instructions to visit him and find out what his condition was. When he came, he found R. Cahana dead. He tore his clothes, then turned them towards his back, and returned weeping. "Is he dead?" they asked him. "You say it, I do not say it," was his reply, adding also (Proverbs 10:18) “And he that spreadeth abroad an evil report is a fool.” (Fol. 4)
5.2: There was a gentile that used to go up and eat the Passover sacrifices in Jerusalem. He said: It is written, no stranger [i.e. gentile] should eat from it; no uncircumcised person shall eat from it, but I eat of the very best. R. Judah b. Bathyra said to him: Did they give you a piece from the fatty tail? No, he replied. When you go there tell them to give you some of the tail. When he went up he said to them, Give me from the fatty tail. They said to him: The fatty tail is sacrificed on the altar.  They said to him: Who told you to do this? He said: R. Judah b. Bathyra. They said: What's going on? They did a background check and discovered that he was a gentile and killed him. Then they sent a message to R. Judah b. Bathyra: Peace be with you, R. Judah b. Bathyra, for you are in Netzivin but your net is spread in Jerusalem.

4.1: R. Joshua b. Levi said: "A man should never bring forth from his mouth an unfit word, for the Scripture uses a circumlocution of eight [extra] letters in order to avoid an ugly word; for it is said (Gen. 4:2) Of the clean beasts and of the beasts that are not clean." R. Papa said: "A circumlocution of nine letters is found in the Scripture; for it is said (Deu. 23:11) If there be among thee, any man that is not lean." Rabina said : "Ten letters [is the circumlocution]; for in the same text there is an an extra letter, Vav." R. Acha b. Jacob said: "Sixteen extra letters are used [in order to avoid an unfit word], as it is said (I Sam. 20:26) For he thought something hath befallen him, he is not clean, because he has not yet purified himself [in order to avoid the word impure]." At the academy of R. Ishmael, it was taught that a man should always speak in clean language, since the seat of a male zab the passage calls (Lev. 15:9) saddle, and the seat of a female zab the passage calls (Ib.) sitting place. This principle is also supported by the following passage (Job 15:6 ) So that thou choosest the language of the prudent. Also by another passage (Ib. 33, 3) And my lips utter knowledge clearly. Why does he cite all these passages [is not the first one sufficient] ? You will perhaps say that this applies only to Biblical matters, but for Rabbinical matters any language might be used. Come, listen; it is said, So that thou choosest a language of the prudent. And if you will say that this applies only to Rabbinical matters, but for secular affairs any language might be used : Come, Listen to this passage : And my lips utter knowledge clearly.

6.0: When Rab, the son of R. Chiya's brother and sister came to Palestine, Rab was asked by R. Chiya: "Is father alive?" "Is mother alive?" was his reply. Then R. Chiya asked him: "Is mother alive?" Rab answered again: "Is father alive?"

200.24: Allowed (to move tzizit) from garment to garment, to light from candle to candle, and the law like Rabbi Shimon in Greirah.
200.25: As it is taught in a braita, Rabbi Shimon says
200.26: A man is allowed to drag a bed, chair, or bench on Shabbat, as long as they do not have the intention to furrow.
200.27: He followed like the stringencies of Rav, but the leniencies he did not follow.
200.20: Taste a little bit, in case while we go back to where we are staying the lamp go out, and we are not Yotzei with his kiddush, for there is no kiddush, only in the place of a meal.
200.23: In everything Master followed like Rav, except for three things did he follow like Shmuel.
200.29: Even with wine you are also taken out of your obligation.
200.1: According to Rav, why do they make Kiddush in the house?
200.0: They have not even completed their obligation for Kiddush.
200.3: And Shmuel, why do they make Kiddush in the synagogue?
200.2: In order to take out his sons and the sons of his house (from the obligation)
200.5: Shmuel goes according to this reasoning, as Shmuel said
200.4: To take the guests (in the shul) out of their obligation. They who eat, drink, and sleep in the synagogue.
200.7: They taught this from that (statement of Shmuel)
200.6: There is no Kiddush, only in the place of a meal.
200.9: Rav Anan Bar Tachlifa said to him:
200.8: These words (limit the case) from house to house, but from place to place in one house - no.
200.10: Many times Shmuel would get up and descend from the roof to the ground floor and he would make Kiddush.
200.13: Rav Huna made Kiddush and then the light went out. He went up to the garden of Rabba Briah where there was light, and he made kiddush and ate a little
200.12: There is no Kiddush, only in the place of a meal.
200.15: There is no Kiddush, only in the place of a meal
200.17: There is no Kiddush only in the place of a meal
200.19: Like when we were in the house of the master and he was making Kiddush and he said:

203.20: Havdalah and Kiddush are one concept, while, Birkat Hamazon  and Kiddush are two entirely different things.
203.21: Leaving this discussion about bundles- Yom Tov that is able to be after shabbos:
203.23: Yakneh( Wine, Kiddush, Fire, Havdalah) And Shmuel said:
203.1: Why?( Why, according to Rabbi Yose's opinion do you use to cups of wine, when the kiddushes in both of them are right next to each other?)
203.0: Once you finish- on the first cup you make Birkat Hamazon, and on the second you make Kiddush.
203.3: Rav Huna said, in the name of Rav Sheshet:
203.2: And we can make both Kiddush and Birkat Hamazon on one cup?!
203.4: You can not recite two blessings on one cup.
203.7: Because one can not do mitzvot in bundles.
203.6: Rav Nachman the son of Rav Yitzchak said:
203.9: Did we not also learn in A beraysa:
203.11: If you do not have more than one cup, you wait until after you are done eating, and recite all the blessings on one cup.
203.10: When you enter your house after Shabbos, bless on the wine, the fire, and the cloves, and after you recite Havdalah on a cup of wine.
203.13: And is there not the example of Yom Tov that is able to fall on Shabbos when there is enough wine. And Rav said:
203.12: If you do not have enough wine, it is different.
203.17: And is there not the example of the first day of yom tov when there is enough wine: and Abaye said:
203.16: That since he did not say Shehechayanu, we are dealing with the seventh day of Pesach, and all that he had(on the first day) was eaten, and is now gone.
203.18: Yakzeneh( Wine, Kiddush, Shehechayanu, Fire, Havdalah) and Rava said: Yaknehaz( Wine, Kiddush Fire, Havdalah, Shehechayanu.

202.13: The rabbis taught in a Beraysa:
202.14: A group of people who were eating, and Shabbos started, somebody is brought a cup of wine and he says Kiddush.  Then, on the second cup you say Birkat Hamazon, according to the opinion of Rabbi Yehudah.
202.16: He may eat until it is dark

149.48: If the dripping fell on [hot] fine flour, one should take [that part of the flour] in a handful [and burn it].
149.49: If one anointed [basted] it with oil that was terumah [a portion of a crop given to a Kohen which becomes holy upon separation, and can only be consumed by Kohanim or their household], and the company appointed to eat it [consists of] Kohanim [members of the priestly caste, a subgroup of tribe of Levi, which is uniquely responsible for maintaining and carrying out the sacrificial services in the Temple], they may eat it; but if it is of [common] Israelites; if it is raw, they must wash it off; if it is [already] roasted, one must peel off the outer [surface].
149.46: Mishnah: If [the roasted lamb] touched the oven's ceramic [surface, that part of the meat] must be peeled off.
149.47: If its juices dripped onto the ceramic, and [dripped] back onto [the lamb, that part of the meat] must be taken off.
149.50: If one anointed [basted] it with oil that was ma'aser sheni [the second tithe of produce, which must be taken to Jerusalem and consumed there], its [value may not be charged] to the company in money, because we may not redeem ma'aser sheni in Jerusalem.

77.28: We fulfill [our obligation] with all [things] that have the taste of marror; we do not fulfill [our obligation] with all [things] that do not have the taste of marror.

229.20: One who swallows both Matza and Maror [without tasting them] satisfies his obligation of Matza, but not his obligation of Maror.
229.19: One who swallows Matza [without tasting it] satisfies his obligation.  One who swallows Maror [without tasting it] does not satisfy his obligation.
229.36: ..."Lehem Oni" - bread that we speak many words.

91.25: [on yom tov] An animal that is close to death one should not shect him only if one can eat from it a roast as big as a olive’s worth on the same day (yom tov).
91.26: One is able to eat it even though he doesn’t need it for food?
91.27: This is reasonable with my opinion, since I hold by this principle of הואיל.    and if one one should want to eat, he is able to feed them.  Becaues of this he may schect.
91.20: (Rabba) Because of a eruv tavshilin we permit something that was forbidden d’orittah!?!
91.22: It is in the Torah that the needs of Shabbat may be done on Yom Tov.  And it was our Rabbis that made the decree, because maybe someone will say that one can bake on yom tov even for Shabbat.
91.23: Because of that, the rabbis required a eruv tavishlin that has a siman (that you can cook on yom tov for shabbat.)
91.28: However, according to your opinion that you said that we do not use the principle of הואיל why is he allowed to schect?
91.1: Rather, separate it and set it aside until after Yom Tov.  If it chametzes, so be it.  (the prohibitions of chametz only applies if the chametz is yours or you are safeguarding it.  Once the challah is set aside for the kohanim, it belongs to the kohanim and we aren’t liable on it.)
91.0: (starts on 46a) Mishnah  : This isn't the hametz that we were warned about it "do not see it" and "do not find it"[in your houses]
91.3: Rabbi Eleizer - reasoned tovat hannah is money and Rabbi Yehoshuah reasoned
91.2: Gemarah : Shall we say that they differed with regards to טובת הנאה?
91.5: No.  they both agree that tovat hanah is not money.  Here they are disagreeing about the principle of הואיל
91.9: We don't use the principle of הואיל
91.10: It was stated with regards to one who bakes on Yom Tov for Chol.  Rav Hisda stated
91.14: he receive lashes (text repeats this line a second time).  Rabbah - Didn’t we sayy “הואיל”  and since visitors might come to him (and eat what he cooked on Yom Tov) it is proper for him to cook (and he shouldn’t receive lashes?)
91.16: He does not recieve lashes because we use this principle of הואיל
91.19: He (Rav Hisda) said we use a eruv tavshlin.
91.18: According to your opinion, that you said we are not using this principle of הואיל, how do we bake on Yom Tov for the needs of Shabbat?
91.31: (Rabba) because of a financial loss we allow that which is forbidden by the Torah?!?
91.30: because of the principle of a great loss of money.
91.33: Yes!  Because of his impending great financial loss, he will resolve in his heart to eat an olive’s worth.  And it is not possible to eat an olive’s worth without schitah.

226.25: (the beraita was taught) before the Heavenly voice, and if you wish to say
226.26: it was after the Heavenly voice and is according to the opinion of Rabbi Yehoshua who said
226.27: "we pay no attention to a Heavenly voice."
226.21: There there are two (reasons) and here there is one (reason), here too there is now two (reasons). Frequent vs. non-frequent, frequent takes precedence.
226.22: And the law is like Bet Hillel.
226.23: That is obvious! For there was a Heavenly voice!
226.28: They brought before him (vegetables for karpas). He dips the lettuce before he reaches the course that is secondary to the matzah.
226.29: They brought before him matzah, lettuce, charoset and two cooked dishes even though charoset isn't a mitzvah.
226.9: He recites the blessing on the day and after he recites the blessing on the wine. Bet Hillel says
226.8: They mixed for him the first cup. Bet Shammai says
226.10: He recites the blessing on the wine and after he recites the blessing on the day.
226.13: He recites the blessing on the day and after he recites the blessing on the wine because it is the day that causes the wine to come. He already sanctified the day and yet the wine has not yet come.
226.12: Matters between Bet Shammai and Bet Hillel concerning meals: Bet Shammai says
226.15: He recites the blessing on the wine and after he recites the blessing on the day because it is the wine that causes the sanctification (kiddush) to be said.
226.17: The blessing of wine is frequent an the blessing of the day is not as frequent. Frequent vs. non-frequent, frequent takes precedence.
226.19: What is the need for "another reason?"
226.18: And the law is like Bet Hillel.
226.30: Rabbi Eliezer the son of Rabbi Tzadok says
226.32: In the time of the Bet HaMikdash, they would bring before him the body of the Pesach offering.

224.6: "Flay a carcass in the market and take your pay and do not say, 'I am a priest, I am a great man and the matter is a disgrace to me.'"

13.0: Our Rabbis taught: one may not search either by the light of the sun or by the light of the moon, or by the light of a torch, save by the light of a lamp, because the light of a lamp is suitable for searching. And though there is no proof of the matter yet there is a hint of it, for it is said, 'seven days shall there be no leaven found [in your houses]'; and it is said, 'and he searched, and began at the eldest, [etc.]'; and it is said, 'and it shall come to pass at that time, that I will search Jerusalem with lamps'; and it is said, 'The soul of a person is the lamp of the Lord, searching all the innermost parts of the belly'.

15.1: R. Elazar said: "Those who go on a religious mission, will not meet with evil either going to, or from, their duty." R. Elazar was in accord with the opinion of the Tanna, Issi b. Juda, who taught: "Since the Torah says (Exodus 34:24) ‘Yet shall no man desire thy land,’ it is to be implied that the cow shall feed in the pasture and no beast shall harm it, the chicken shall dig in the rubbish and no weasel shall harm it." Now, can this not be inferred a fortiori? If, regarding the things which are exposed to injury, it is promised that no harm will occur, how much the more so regarding things that are usually not exposed to injury? This conclusion I could only arrive at with reference to protection while on the way to perform [a meritorious act]. Whence, however, do we infer that even on the return, no harm will occur? It is said (Deuteronomy 16:7) ‘And thou shalt turn in the morning and go unto thy tents.’ From this passage we may learn that Thou wilt go and find thy tents in peace. Since even on the return [he will meet no evil], wherefore is it necessary to mention [the protection] on the way going to perform the religious duty? We must therefore say this statement is necessary for the reference to what R. Ami said: "Every man who has land is in duty bound to visit Jerusalem during the festivals, but a man who has no land need not visit Jerusalem during the festivals." R. Abin b. R. Adda said in the name of R. Isaac: "Why was there not Gennesar-fruit in the land of Israel? Lest those who visit Jerusalem during the festivals should say, 'Had we come here merely to enjoy of the Gennesar-fruit: it would have been sufficient.' Hence their visit would become not as a matter of duty." The same said R. Dastoe b. Janai: "Why are not the hot springs of Tiberias located in Jerusalem? For the simple reason that those who visit Jerusalem during the festivals, should not say, 'Were it for nothing else than to bathe ourselves in the hot springs of Tiberias that we visited Jerusalem, it would have been sufficient! Thus their visiting Jerusalem would turn out to be not as a matter of duty."

14.1: And not [by the light of] a torch? Surely Raba said, What is the meaning of the verse, "And his brightness was as the light; he had rays coming forth from his hand: and there was hiding of his power?" To what are the righteous comparable in the presence of the Shechinah? To a lamp in the presence of a torch. And Raba also said: [To use] a torch for havdalah is the most preferable [way of performing this] duty? — Said R. Nahman b. Isaac: The one can be brought into holes and chinks [in the wall], whereas the other cannot be brought into holes and chinks. R. Zebid said: The one [throws] its light forward, whereas the other [throws] its light behind. R. Papa said: Here [with a torch] one is afraid, whereas there [with a lamp] one is not afraid. Rabina said: The light of the one is steady, whereas that of the other is fitful.
14.0: This light of the sun, where is it meant? Shall we say, in a courtyard, — but Raba said: A courtyard does not require searching, because birds frequent it. While if in a hall, but Raba said: A hall is searched by its own light? — This is meant only in respect of a skylight in a room. But [then] what part of it? If [that which is] opposite the skylight, then it is the same as a hall? — Rather, it means [the part of the room] at the sides.

216.10: ... What should people celebrate with? with wine
216.13: ... For men what is suitable - with wine, and what for women?
216.12: ... Men with what is suitable for them and women with what is suitable for them.
216.15: ... In Bavel, buying women coloured clothes. In Eretz Yisrael, buying women ironed linen clothes.
216.17: "While the Temple is standing, there is no joy unless there is meat, as it says (Deut. 27) 'And you shall sacrifice peace-offerings and eat them there, and you will be joyful before the Lord, your God'.
216.16: It was taught: R' Yehuda b. Beteira says:
216.18: Now that the Temple is not standing, there is no joy without wine, as it says (Psalms 104) ' And wine will rejoice the heart of man.'"
216.1: They said about Rabbi Akiva that he would distribute to the children grain and walnuts on Erev Pesach so that they should not fall asleep and they should ask
216.0: grain and walnuts on Erev Pesach in order that they should not fall asleep and they should ask.
216.3: We snatch Matzot on the night of Pesach in order that the children do not sleep.
216.2: It was taught in a Beraita. Rabbi Eliezer says:
216.5: In all his days he never said "It is time to get up from the House of Study" except for Erev Pesach and Erev Yom Kippur.
216.4: It was taught in a Beraita. They said about Rabbi Akiva
216.7: and on Erev Yom Kippur in order that they should feed their children.
216.6: On Erev Pesach, in order that the children don't sleep
216.9: A person must celebrate with his sons and the members of his household on a festival, as it says (Devarim 16:14) "you shall celebrate on your festivals".
